question.body: In the autoimmune disease myasthenia gravis, the bodyâ€™s own immune system attacks acetylcholine nicotinic receptors. This prevents signal transmission and, eventually, results indeath of the motor end-plate. How does this work?

multiple_choice.choice: Acetylcholine cannot reach the blocked receptors, and the signal is blocked.
Antibodies rupture the vesicles and prevent acetylcholine release, and the signal is blocked.
Neurons use choline molecules to produce antibodies instead of acetylcholine, so there is no acetylcholine to be transferred.
Calcium ion movement is altered by antibody binding, and the signal is blocked.

response.feedback: Correct. When acetylcholine nicotinic receptors are blocked, the acetylcholine cannot reach the receptors, so the signal is inhibited.
Incorrect. Acetylcholine is kept in vesicles, but the vesicles are not ruptured, since they are contained inside neurons.
Incorrect. Antibodies, produced by immune cells, are large proteins.
Incorrect. It is possible that calcium flux is altered, but the primary mechanism is via the acetylcholine and acetylcholine nicotinic receptors.
